title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: White gates have an evil name still, and Muckle Haws was full of horrors

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: Muckle Haws was fascinated by Johnny's sneers at superstition, and sometimes on dark nights the inventor had to make his courage good by seeing the farmer past the doulie yates (ghost gates), which Muckle Havrs had to go perilously near on his way home.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: Muckle Haws was fascinated by Johnny's sneers at superstition, and sometimes on dark nights the inventor had to make his courage good by seeing the farmer past the doulie yates (ghost gates), which Muckle Havrs had to go perilously near on his way home.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: Johnny only took to literature after he had made his name, and he seldom spoke at the club except when ghosts and the like v^^ere the subject of debate, as they tended to be when the farmer of Muckle Haws could get in a word.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: " Once, just before the cattle market, he was sent round by a local laird to announce that any drover found taking the short cut to the hill through the grounds of Muckle Plowy, would be prosecuted  to the utmost limits of the law.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: It was a paper bag glittering  with gold braid, and contained such an assortment  of sweets as lads bought for their lasses on the Muckle Friday.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: This travelling show visited us regularly twice a year : once in summer  for the Muckle Friday, when the performers were gay and stout, and even the horses had flesh on their bones ; and again in the "back- end " of the year, when cold and hunger had taken the blood from their faces, and the scraggy dogs that whined at their side were lashed for licking the paint off the caravans.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: On the Muckle Friday, the fair for which children storing their pocket- money would accumulate sevenpence halfpenny in less than six months, the square was crammed with gingerbread stalls, bag-pipers, fiddlers, and monstrosities who were gifted with second-sight
